properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Additional snowfall: 2 to 4 cm. Time span: continuing until early Tuesday morning. Maximum winds: northerly gusting to 60 km/h. Locations: Eagle River section of the Trans-Labrador Highway. Remarks: Conditions will gradually improve through tonight and into early Tuesday. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-08T10:59:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-07T19:48:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3714087020.2020
Area: Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are expected to continue this evening. Strong winds continue to blow through the Richardson Mountains this evening, likely leading to reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Winds are expected to ease somewhat overnight, but areas of blowing snow are likely to persist through the night. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-08T15:30:01-00:00

Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall continues tonight, but conditions will improve on Tuesday as snow tapers off to flurries. Additional amounts: 5 to 10 cm Time span: tonight. Locations: Cartwright to Lodge Bay. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A series of fronts will bring upwards of 100 mm of rain across the central coast and northern Vancouver Island by Tuesday morning. While warning level rainfall criteria may not be reached, the total rainfall amount may still trigger localised flooding, debris flow or road washouts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-08T14:05:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-08T02:24:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1139830648.2020
Area: North Vancouver Island, Central Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense frontal system is moving across the BC Coast tonight. Rain, heavy at times, is occurring over East Vancouver Island near Bowser. Total rainfall amounts of 50 to 70 mm is expected. The heavy rain will ease by Tuesday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-08T14:59:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-08T02:24:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3779247231.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant Snowfall for Tuesday night and Wednesday. Locations: Eastern half of the Island, excluding the Avalon and Burin peninsulas. Possible snowfall: Generally 10 to 20 cm with potential for higher amounts locally. Winds: Generally northeasterly 40 gusting to 60 km/h with stronger coastal gusts. Some areas along the south and east coasts could see gusts approach 100 km/h. Remarks: The cause of this disruption to our lack of winter weather will be a deep low pressure system passing near the Avalon Peninsula. Snow will begin on Tuesday evening and persist in some areas until Wednesday afternoon. Temperatures are expected to be near zero, which means areas along the coast may see the snow mix with or change completely over to rain. Unfortunately, this also means the snow is likely going to be rather wet and heavy. We will also likely see a period of freezing rain and ice pellets over the easternmost regions Tuesday night into Wednesday morning. Extra considerations for the Clarenville area and the Bonavista Peninsula: These areas are expected to be right along the snow-rain line. If the storm track shifts further northwest, precipitation in these areas could easily be mostly rain, with up to 30 mm possible instead of snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-08T18:59:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-08T03:00:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1900253835.2020
Area: Connaigre, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense frontal system will move across the BC Coast bringing heavy rain to the region tonight and Tuesday. Heavy rain will develop later this evening over the Fraser Valley, Metro Vancouver, and Howe Sound. Total rainfall accumulations of 60 to 90 mm are expected through Tuesday morning. The heavy rain will ease by midday Tuesday. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-08T15:31:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-07T23:32:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1641026434.2020

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog patches continue to persist this evening in the Whiteshell area and extreme southeast Manitoba. The fog is expected to gradually dissipate later this evening as a drier westerly flow enters the region. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-08T10:59:47-00:00

properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Heavy snow is forecast for Highway 93 starting this evening and tapering off late in the day on Tuesday. Total snowfall amounts are expected to reach near 25 cm over the highest elevations of the highway. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Locations: Gander and Vicinity and Bonavista North. Time span: Tuesday evening until Wednesday afternoon. Remarks: Snowfall amounts nearing 15 cm are expected by Wednesday morning, with additional accumulations occuring during the day Wednesday. Temperatures will remain near or slightly above zero, so this snow will be wet and heavy. Strong northwesterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h will develop on Wednesday, but due to the compact nature of the snow, the risk of widespread blowing snow is low. Conditions are expected to improve late in the day on Wednesday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-08T18:58:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-08T02:59:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1166944065.2020
Area: Bonavista North, Gander and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind and rain likely for Tuesday night and Wednesday. Locations: The Avalon Peninsula. Possible rainfall: 25 to 40+ mm Winds: Generally northeasterly 40 gusting to 60 km/h with stronger coastal gusts. Some areas could see gusts approach 100 km/h on Wednesday as winds shift to northwesterly. Remarks: A deep low pressure system will track near the Avalon Peninsula. While it seems likely that precipitation will be mainly rain, the snow-rain line is expected to be near the isthmus. If the track of the low were to shift further southeast, significant snowfall could be possible over the western Avalon. Rainfall warnings are not expected at this point, since the ground is not frozen and there is no snowpack. Under these circumstances, 50 mm of rain in 24 hours would be required for a warning. Conditions will improve by Wednesday afternoon or evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-08T18:58:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-08T02:59:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1177918441.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions will affect this community tonight and Tuesday. Near-zero visibilities are expected in the snow and blowing snow. Protect yourself from the wind, cold conditions and desorientation by staying sheltered, inside. A blizzard warning is issued when winds are expected to reduce visibilities in the widespread blowing snow at 400 metres or less for at least 6 hours. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-08T19:11:25-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected tonight before changing to snow on Tuesday morning. Several hours of freezing rain may result in ice accumulations of up to 2 millimeters in some locations. Ice pellets or snow may mix with freezing rain, especially toward the community of Fort Severn. This may serve to reduce ice accumulations. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-08T19:22:37-00:00

Area: Fort Severn, Sachigo Lake - Bearskin Lake, Big Trout Lake - Kasabonika

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Overnight tonight and into Tuesday, very strong winds are expected with wind gusts as high as 120 to 130 km/h. These winds will gradually diminish Tuesday afternoon. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A frontal system moving across the BC interior tonight and Tuesday will bring heavy snow to the Columbias. Across the West Columbia region, wet snow at times mixed with rain near Revelstoke will continue tonight. Local amounts of 15 cm of wet snow are expected before snow changes to rain Tuesday morning. For the North Columbia region - including Blue River, snow will switch over to rain early Tuesday morning. For the Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass, Yoho Park and East Columbia regions, heavy snow will taper off to periods of light snow later in the day on Tuesday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-08T19:35:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-08T03:36:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1274215984.2020
Area: Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Periods of freezing rain can be expected in parts of Northern Manitoba this afternoon through this evening as a series of disturbances moves through the area. While some communities will see little accumulation, others could see a few hours of freezing rain with significant ice accumulation. The freezing rain should end either this evening or overnight as the system moves into Northern Ontario. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
